Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2011 04:39PM - edited Apr 18, 2011 04:41PM by cc4npg carberry:  So you have Rainbow Henna? Like I said, I use a two step process with Light Mountain Color the Gray products, but the body art quality henna is recommended by most.  Rainbow is supposed to be very good too.  You can probably find Light Mountain at your local health food store (call to see).  If you have a lot of gray, I would suggest a two step process.  The two step process is basically this... the first step contains 100% Henna only, which leaves gray/white hair orange.  Step two contains your indigo or cassia or whatever color you want to tone the red down.  So, if your hair is more than 10% gray, I'd suggest using a step one of pure henna.  Here are some tips:  use ONLY distilled water; do NOT use anything metal unless you want green hair; if using coffee, double the amt of coffee to make it really strong.  You can add just about anything to henna!  But be careful, sometimes less is more.  I only use very strong coffee, and add espresso instant coffee to my second step to achieve my color.  Also, bear in mind you might want to do a spot test to see how long you want to leave the henna on.  Some people leave it on for an hour, some for 6 hours.  Some use heat like a hair dryer to get the color to set quicker, some don't.  Heat can bring out more of a red color.  Use plastic gloves, take off rings.  Have old towels handy.  Get plastic hair caps or plastic wrap.  Prior to using Henna, wash your hair but do NOT use conditioner.  You may use baking soda or a little conditioner after dying to remove all of henna.  Don't rewash your hair though and it's best not to use conditioner.  The color of Henna will change over 72 hours as it oxidizes.  PM me if you have questions.  The link below will take you to a page of real people's pictures and their recipes. Henna Recipes

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2011 02:13AM cc4npg wrote: Henna... it's natural... it's a plant... it leaves a red cast as a rule.  You can use indigo to help mask the red, or change it.  You can use other things to mix it with to change the color too, like coffee.  You can add some spices too.  Imagine for a moment MUD in a pudding or yorgurt kind of consistency.  Now imagine putting that in your hair.  That's pretty much what henna is.  You put it in, you leave it in... depending on what how dark you want it, or how difficult your hair may be to color.  Some people leave it on overnight.  I use the Light Mountain brand, called Color the Grey.  It's a two step process.  The first step I use distilled water to mix, and it turns my grey hair (or used to when I had hair) bright orange.  The second step I mix with very strong, day old coffee, and leave it in longer.  When done, it's a nice brownish/red.  NEVER use anything metal with henna unless you want a possible green color.  Henna takes a few hours to oxidize after it's put on.  The color changes during this period of time.  It is messy... it smells funny, sorta like dirt... it's difficult to get out completely.  I use baking soda to help get it out.  You're not supposed to use shampoo or conditioner right after using henna... just rinse it out well and let it dry (oxidize).  It thickens your hair because it coats eat follicle.  It is actually a good conditioner, but it does dry out the hair... quite a bit actually when you use it to color.  (They have henna that is strictly used as a conditioner and you don't use it as often)  It's a lot better for you than the chemicals in permanent hair color.  Henna is a permanent color.  It's supposed to fade over time, but mine never did.  However I did color every 4 weeks or so too, so maybe it does over time.  One more thing.. if you have chemical dye on your hair, you need to wait 5-6 weeks before doing henna or you might get an unwanted color.  Same thing if you switch from henna to chemical dye.  Also, after coloring with henna, since it is harder to get out, you may want to put an older shirt on as it dries.  Henna will color your hands or anything it touches. To me, the pros outweigh the cons.  Even with the mess and time, I'd rather put something less harmful on my hair.  And when done correctly, the result is absolutely gorgeous.

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2011 10:01PM cc4npg wrote: Regarding Henna and the use of chemical dye again... Here's what I know.  When I wanted to use Henna, I was told to wait at least 6 weeks after my last chemical dye before using it.  I had no problems.  Using it too soon after a chemical treatment (dye, perm) can leave green hair.  The same applies when switching from Henna to chemical dye.  I was told if I ever want to go back to chemical dye (not that I would), I would need to wait about 6 weeks after using Henna in order to use chemical dye.  You can also use Crystal Light Lemonaide in an attempt to get Henna off your hair (I don't know how well that works).  But you shouldn't have to cut your hair in order to use chemical after Henna.

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2010 02:31PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 05:56AM by cc4npg meglove:  I second what Janet said... you will do fine!  These last few days are the pits.  Nervous or anxious doesn't even begin to describe how I felt prior to surgery.  The morning of surgery, I dropped off my child at daycare, arrived at the clinic, talked to my BS, expressed my anxiety and asked for Versed which they gave to me right after talking to my BS.  I remember "maybe" 5 minutes after speaking to him, and then I heard my name and was being wheeled down the hall to my room AFTER my surgery!  So yeah, I will definitely ask for Versed for every surgery from now on... it's my best friend drugwise!  Let us know when you get home. I didn't feel much like eating after surgery, but I remember being really hungry!  I had the same thing though, I would get full really fast.  Know clue if I've lost weight... I hope not.  I only weighed 102 to begin with! I seem to be continuing to recover very well - 8 days out now.  I was really sore under my armpits this morning, and my sides hurt now from the bruising.  It's strange how at first I didn't feel all the bruises, and now as I start to heal, I'm feeling more.  My right breast has perhaps a little fluid buildup or something and looks larger than the left.  It may be just some puffy swelling.  I hope they both even out and feel they will.  Both nipples look really good... nice color, no blackness at all, and I am pleased to have feeling in the right already.  My incision went beneath the areola and up at a slant toward my armpit.  I have stitches and a long steri strip over top of it.  They'll come out Monday, so I'm going to try to get the tape off Sunday to prevent unnecessary pulling by the doc.  The tight feeling is going away and now only feels like a slightly tight bra.  I actually am already larger than I was prior to surgery toward the top of my breasts.  I never had tissue at the upper parts of my chest and the tissue expander actually fills in the space quite nicely so I really haven't missed the tissue.  I have almost complete range of motion now, but I still move slow.  No pathology back yet, and I'm praying for nothing new and perhaps better news than I've had in the past 60 days.

Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2010 08:27PM cc4npg wrote: I had bilateral Thursday the 7th, and was told not to remove anything until my PS appt Monday the 11th.  My advice... wait until the appt.  I peeked from the top of the dressing, but I never took it off.  You certainly don't want to introduce any bacteria.  If you're running a fever, or if the upper portion of your chest looks red or feels hot, then you need to call your PS or BS immediately.  If you try to peek around the side of the dressing to see where the tube goes into the skin, be very careful not to put your fingers in the dressing too much... again we don't want infection.  If you would see anything oozing green or nasty yellow... again that could be infection and you should call your doc.  Chances are, though, that the sloshing you hear is additional fluid that hasn't drained.  Your PS will know what to do, and if in doubt, give him a call and bounce it off him... tonight.
Posts.Title: October 2010 Mastectomy cc4npg cc4npg

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2010 08:16PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 05:59AM by cc4npg Hi guys!  I'm still doing what I consider to be great on recovery.  I do still have a lot of pressure, discomfort, and under arms is still quite tender, but probably almost 100% range of motion.  I am having a lot of problems with emotions right now.  I was so relieved and happy after surgery, and now I'm dreading my next step... chemo.  I know I'm normal, but it's so hard to control emotions around family, and then I feel guilty about it because I know I'm bringing everyone down!  Then that makes me upset... and it's a vicious circle. I went for my first onc appt today.  My onc is female, and has a little accent but not too bad.  She went over everything I already knew... how BC starts... how DCIS starts... how it becomes invasive, etc.  Apparently I was part of probably a lengthy discussion regarding my case, because she's calling my triple negative an "incidental finding".  I didn't have a lump... or pain.. or a mass.. just 4 microcalcifications on mammo.  The biopsy apparently got all the invasive part out (stereotactic).  However, they weren't able to determine the size of it because it was done thru a needle and it was fragmented.  She went on to say it was definitely under 1 cm... well, I should think so if the DCIS was only .9 x .8 cm on final path.  If we knew the cancer was under 5 mm, then chemo wouldn't be recommended, but, being that we don't, she is recommending 4 rounds of Taxotere/Cytoxin.  So on one hand I'm like, cool... no Adriamycin (Red Devil).  But on the other hand, I'm like, ok, so should it be Cytoxin or Carboplatin?  She is ok with either, so now I'm trying to find more info on it.  I asked her about Dose Dense, and about weekly doses.  She feels that's overkill with my cancer being very small, possibly right at the gray area.  The only main reasons she's even suggesting chemo is because of size unknown, and because of my age (43).  She also definitely recommended ooph.  So I need to schedule that probably for December or January.  Assuming I'm feeling up to it.  She said it was not that big a deal really, but I'd still have a 2% chance of cancer there due to no hysterectomy.  Some of you have been thru the ooph... I'm premenopausal... will I be ok? I just feel down this week.  I should be so upbeat having such a good outcome, so I feel badly for feeling down.  Good news is, if I start chemo mid November, I'll be done by around March 1st!  I HATE winter, so if I have to have chemo, this is better for me.  Bad news is... the holidays may not be so great, my birthday is in January too, and oh yeah, I have to get my license renewed so I'll be chemo-girl for 4 years on my license.  I may get it redone after hair comes back.

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2010 04:00AM cc4npg wrote: I wanted to remind all of us that we and our bodies have been through a MAJOR TRAMATIC experience AND MAJOR SURGERY.  I have cried since my surgery... for a lot of reasons... emotions are up and down... then we have pain... trying to cope with what's next... possible chemo... possible more surgery (in my case)... so, to me, it's completely normal to question everything.  It takes about a year to completely heal from a surgery, period.  I don't think there's a time limit on a cancer diagnosis.  Certainly, we all have to be strong... and "deal" with it... but I don't feel very strong sometimes and tell myself it's ok to have the emotions I'm having.  I'm thankful for this board and the people on it, for those that have prayed for me, and for the opportunity to help others.

Posts.Content: Oct 27, 2010 08:35PM cc4npg wrote: JanetinVirginia:  Great news on the BRCA!!  I hope your daughter's is negative too!! So I had a second opinion today.  I asked about the oncotype test, and it isn't recommended for triple negatives and is only used mainly for hormone positive people with early stage to determine if chemo is necessary.  I went to the state university for my opinion, and the onc's there pretty much agree with my first onc... 4 rounds of TC every 3 weeks.  However, my case is of interest to them and they want to test the tissues again to verify I did actually have IDC and not just DCIS.  I can't imagine I had only DCIS... the tissue from biopsy was stained to see that it was invasive... and when I said this to the onc, he said that it was more of how the staining was interpreted, thus the interpretation may have been wrong.  Well, it'd sure be cool not to have to have chemo but I'm not holding my breath.  So I'll know something more on that in a couple of weeks.  I wish I was closer to the university because I really liked them better, but I can't see driving slightly over an hour one way in the winter to have chemo.  He agreed and said the treatment drugs were the same no matter what area of the country you're in.  They were really nice and I'd highly recommend them for a 2nd opinion to anyone.

Posts.Content: Nov 2, 2010 09:55AM cc4npg wrote: MSHH:  Hi!  Welcome but sorry to see you here!  I have TE's too... so far healing wonderfully.  Sometimes tissue can have problems with healing, but often it turns itself around and is fine.  Occassionally the surgeon has to intervene.  Just make sure he's aware of any issues quickly to stay on top of what's going on.  Will be praying for everything to heal nicely for you! alhaun:  I felt weird for the first several days too.  My head was not all there.  My vision was in and out.  I just felt completely weird.  Many things cause this... anesthesia, pain meds, trauma.  Drink plenty of water and see if you notice any of your pain meds causing it.  I weaned myself off of them pretty quick and my head cleared a few days after.  Oh, and get plenty of rest.  I noticed my head felt much clearer after a nap.  Good to hear from you! I had my first fill yesterday.  PS put in 50 ml, so I'm up to 75 now.  I notice my right (noncancer) TE seems placed really well.  That boob is filling out really well and looks real nice.  My left TE is placed a bit higher.  And it appears smaller than the right.  I think it's because the lower pole isn't down as far as the right.  I've been massaging it but my TE's have sutured tabs so I doubt I will get it to move down.  A little concerned about final appearance, but I've been told he will try to do pocket work, and move it down.  He also mentioned fat grafting, and then said he doubted he'd find any on me!  LOL  I'm 100 lbs now and trying to gain to 105.  I had a rough night last night due to the expansion I believe.  Just uncomfortable and mild pain in certain ways I'd lay.  I feel fine now that I'm up.  Getting ready to go to Cali this week, so if I you don't hear from me for a few days, that's why!  Goodbye cold, hello hot!

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2010 11:10AM cc4npg wrote: Leigh:  Sorry to see you here, but so glad you found us.  I echo what others have said above.  I'm the same way... the "rock" in the family.  I'm the one who holds too much of other people's problems together, finding answers for problems, taking on too much, and the one they come to in an emergency.  I'm 43 and have had endless energy until this diagnosis.  It's zapped me from the inside out.  The emotional stress is so heavy, that even without the anesthesia or meds we'd be a mess!  This is not your fault, so don't be dissapointed in yourself!  This is something you don't have control of, and that's what makes it so hard, because most of us are used to being in control.  If you haven't already done so, get a second opinion set up.  And you are NOT a statistic!  I read your other post.  Don't pay attention to the stats too much, because we are individuals!  I read a LOT... too much actually... and have read people who have had way more nodes involved who are alive and well 10+ years later.  And I've read those who had NO lymph nodes involved, whose cancers were very tiny, who went on to having recurrences.  So you can't go by all the numbers, and someone has to fall on the good side, so we'll believe it's going to be YOU.  I'll pray for you, because that's the only thing I know to be concrete and never failing. I got my second opinion results today.  OSU retested my tissue, and found my IDC at biopsy to be .3 cm (3 mm).  They said there was a super tiny bit of microinvasion seen in the mastectomy.  But even with my IDC being only 3 mm, the onc there says he'd recommend 4 rounds of TC because I'm triple negative and I'm only 43.  The general gray area is for cancers less than .5 cm, often leading to no chemo, so it really looks like I'll do the chemo even with it being tiny.  I don't think I could forgive myself if I didn't do the chemo and a year later found it spreading.  I'm very afraid of the SE's, so I'm a bit down today, but God is in control of it all.  I worry about memory, vision, and SE's that might be long term.  So I'll be reading more about these things now to prepare myself.  Four months from now, I'll be done, so it doesn't seem too bad when I look at it that way.

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2010 07:31PM cc4npg wrote: meglove:  My advice on wisdom teeth extraction is to ask both the dentist performing the extraction, as well as your BS.  I think it may be ok to do, but the drawback is obviously the risk of infection.  However, you'll be on antibiotics after they're pulled so honestly I bet it'll be ok.  Just ask the professionals to be sure, and post to let us know what they said!  Never know when someone else will come along with the same question. Leanna9:  LVI... simply put, from what I've read, this means there is a chance the cancer has spread via the veins, but it doesn't mean it has.  Do a google search.  I will also tell you from what I've read that those who have absent LVI doesn't necessarily mean the cancer has NOT spread.  It's all confusing and pretty much none of us know what these nasty cells are or are not doing because they're sneaky.  I agree... get another opinion and ask questions.

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2010 09:35PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 12:23PM by cc4npg My understanding from the makers of Neupogen is that this drug can cause tachycardia in about 1 in 4000 people.  And get this, when I told the oncologist who was at the hospital about neupogen causing the tachycardia, she's like, that would be highly rare to happen.  I'm like, duh... and then I told her, "Think about it this way, I'm 43, white, no real history of BC in my family at all other than a half sister, I'm BRCA2 positive with triple negative BC!"  Normally, BRCA2 is ER+!!  She stopped me part way through.. I guess she got the point I was making.  Seriously, LISTEN to me!  I most often know whereof I speak, and someone has to fall in that small percentage who has one rare side effect, right?  It really angers me that they didn't figure this out themselves... that I had to do it for them.  That is bothersome.  So believe me my next onc appt I'm going to have something printed out from the Neupogen website regarding this side effect and the preventative to it.  As for my pulse right now, it's been hovering in the 90's to 104 so I feel it's coming down.  Otherwise, I feel good.  Oh, and I think I may be getting ready to lose my hair... my head is really sore. Neulasta shouldn't cause me to have tachycardia.  So far I haven't found anything saying it might anyway, but I'm looking again now.

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2010 03:42PM cc4npg wrote: Annette S:  Hi!  Sorry to see you here, but we're all in the same or similar boat.  Honestly I'd love to jump out of the boat, but alas, the waves are too big and I'm not a good swimmer.  My story goes something like this... Abnormal mammo beginning of August, biopsy beginning of September, met with plastic surgeon 9/27, surgery 10/7.  If I were you, I'd call both doc's and ask for a preliminary date asap after talking to the plastic surgeon.  They have to coordinate their schedules, and I was a very squeaky wheel.  What have you been told so far?  When were you diagnosed?  See if you can get your doc's to go with a date the week after you meet with the plastic surgeon.  That's what I did.  The sooner you get it done, the better you will be mentally... trust me on that one.  Keep us posted! So, Vicodin made me a little itchy and they switched me to Darvocet.  Darvocet gave me nausea and a sick headache yesterday.  I finally made myself drink more water to flush it out and took Ibuprofen last night.  I don't feel so sick today at least.  I don't do well on pain meds, and I think it's because I am such a lightweight.  I don't take medicine unless I absolutely have to, so my body is simply not used to all that stuff.  My arms feel stiff.  Breathing is getting slightly better I think.  I tried very gentle stretches today with my arms... nothing major.  Seems like I have better range of motion to the prophylactic side than the cancer side, probably because of node removal?  I'm nervous for my PS appt tomorrow.  I know he'll take the compression bandage off and not sure how that will feel.  I don't like pain.  I may take a Vicodin before the appt just in case.  Janet?  Do you have any suggestions on that?  I took pictures before surgery, and took one of the compression bandage for the picture forum.  I'll take another one tomorrow when he takes off the bandage.  Then I'll have to figure out how to post them.  I get itches under my arms, but when I try to scratch I can't feel anything so I don't know where to scratch!  It's the weirdest feeling ever.  I've had other surgeries so thankfully I know the numbness is because of the nerve damage and a lot of that will eventually come back... probably not all, but a lot.  And I know it can take up to a year to fully recover from a major surgery.  Can I skip the next several months?  I have Chemo still ahead of me, and the ovaries and fallopian tubes to be removed, so yeah... Lord?  It's me again...  Also, I'm noticing it's harder for me to focus on my clock across the room.  I wonder if that's the left over anesthesia or what?  I can see, but I have to really concentrate and focus sometimes.  I keep telling myself I've had major surgery, and so I need to take it easy and not expect as much of myself.  Oh, and I have yet to have a BM since surgery Thursday.  I don't feel stopped up, but I think I may take a stool softener just to be safe.

Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2010 08:39PM cc4npg wrote: I have that same feeling in the morning... I have to sit up and magically, that helps.  I haven't decided on implant type yet.  If you're in the US, they don't have the gummies approved yet, but I'm leaning on smooth silicone from what I've read. A word about cold caps.  Go to the actual website and read what you must do for them to work.  You have to start with them on somewhere around 30 minutes prior to chemo.  They have to be changed something like every 20 minutes... and have to remain frozen at the right temp until needed... so you'll need dry ice if your doc won't freeze them for you.  EVERY 20 minutes or so, before, during and 2 hours or so AFTER chemo treatments.  You'll need enough caps to get you through that entire time.  It does add up money wise.  Also, from the website, you'll need one or two people to stay with you during the treatment.  They have to help you put on the cold caps the right way every 20 minutes or so. As to them working, I've heard good things.  Some people still have hair loss.  If you don't get them on right, you'll lose hair in those areas.  The cancer cells being on the scalp is a question... some docs believe it is very unlikely, but no one really knows.  I don't know the percentage of people these actually have worked for, but there are a lot who swear by them. For me, I won't be getting them... per advice from my cancer treatment coordinator.  I'd love to keep my hair, and will pray for it's quick return... maybe I'll have curls!  My hair has always been fairly straight.  It was past my waist prior to dx, but I cut 18" off before mx and now it's to my shoulder blades!  I will probably get it cut short prior to first treatment, in preparation for losing it.  I've read many journey's here of people who had this same treatment we're having, and so far they've gotten their hair back.  Yes, I know, there are a couple who didn't... I saw them too... very disturbing and frightening especially when we thought everyone would get it back.  We have about a 95% chance of getting it back, so I think that's pretty good.

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2010 10:52AM cc4npg wrote: myrrl:  Sleeping on your side is tricky.  I'm a side sleeper too.  And yes, my arms went numb for a while.  I would take a Percocet prior to bedtime to ease the pain, sometimes 1/2 one when I went to bed, and another 1/2 during the night.  When I laid down, I would gently go to my side and carefully slide the one arm under on that one side.  I found if I held the TE up at the side where I was trying to slide my arm, it helped a bit.  Yes, it was painful upon waking until I was able to sit up and sometimes it felt like the TE would get in a pinched position.  Maybe if you double a washcloth and slide between your arm and side of the TE you're laying on that would help.  It has gotten easier and actually my TE's were more uncomfortable empty than they are now after 75 ml.  My next fill is Monday. Looks like my warm weather trip has about come to a close.   I'm ready to come home, just not to the cold.  Hurry up Spring!

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2010 03:10AM cc4npg wrote: I'm continuing to heal, and feel really good.  I probably should make sure to do more stretching too... been lax recently.  I will start chemo probably next week.  Went to onc today, and I'm in a very gray area.  I knew that, being my tumor was 3 mm.  To do, or not to do, that was the question.  Triple negative tells me to do it, because I have nothing else to fight with, so chemo wins.  I got a wig today.. fairly long, really pretty.  Since 2006, my family has had almost constant bad news, or always something replacing the last emergency... today, it was my daughter.  Long story short, she has 3 lower front teeth that appear may need root canals.  Xray showed a very dark area encompassing all 3, so I spent most of the afternoon on the phone trying to find someone to take her insurance.  I have to make more calls tomorrow.  She's on antibiotics, but she also has a hole in her heart (born with it).. so this is something that has to get fixed fast.  I feel for her, she's an adult and not taking very good care of herself but I can only do so much.  I made sure she was healthy for 18 years.  It just seems like it's literally one thing after another with our family. But I feel good... really good... almost so good I forget I have to face chemo and more surgery.  Blah... I hate this cancer thing... I hope I never hear from it again!

Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2010 02:02AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 12:16PM by cc4npg eileen:  Well, my doc at the time of the possible histo didn't even refer me to see a specialist.  I wanted to see one just to make sure all was ok, and that was prior to the BC dx.  The ct in early June found scaring at the top of my lungs, several calcified 1-2 mm nodules, some 1-2 mm nodules in both fields that were not calcified, a little infiltrate, and residual reticulonodular lung process.  It also found 2 nodules on the left in the 6 mm range that were not calcified but didn't enhance, and 1 nodule on the left in the pleural area that didn't enhance.  Thus the radiologist believed it was highly unlikely I had anything going on other than some type of infection.  When I read the report, knowing what I do being a nurse aide, the very first thing I thought about was TB... followed by pnuemonia.  I'd had 3 TB tests early this year... 2 before getting sick, and one while I was sick... all negative.  The antibiotics cleared up whatever infection I had, and I've had no symptoms of it since.  The pulmonologist ran some blood tests last week too, one being an in depth look for TB.  I know for a fact if that had come back positive, I would have gotten an immediate call!  So yes, histo is scary as well as really common in certain parts of the country.  My BS was aware of my illness and said he had lung nodules too.  Yes, it still messes with my mind even though my nodes were clear.  I have to remind myself of the logical aspects... nodes clear... invasive portion removed at biopsy... grade 2... no lympho/vascular invasion noted.. and invasive portion was only 3 mm.  Those things combined tell me it would be illogical to think this is in any way connected to cancer.  I don't smoke thank God... yes, I did a little when I was a young adult, but it was just social or passive.  I was actually allergic to the smoke!  LOL  Anyway, yes my symptoms are gone.  I have no idea how I got it either.  I dug a trench (french drain) last year around my house, but I think it would have hit me sooner than this year unless it was dormant. This year has been horrible for me.  Every time I go in for something wrong or for some kind of test, I find myself becoming very nervous and anxious.  I know it's normal... I've read hundreds of posts describing the same thing!  I wish cancer didn't leave us fearing things so much.  It's like... I want to be done with the cancer, and have the treatment over with... but then it hits me that no one is ever really sure "when" it's over.  It's that darkness that haunts us for many years, if not for the rest of our lives.  I'm really considering, once I'm done with treatment, looking into some type of light hypnosis that would enable me to not worry about it so much.

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2010 07:34AM cc4npg wrote: EastCoastGrl:  There's nothing you can really say to the well meaning people who assume since we had mx, all of it should be gone.  I've tried to explain the details, and it takes about an hour in all honesty to explain the basic things about cancer, the type I have, and the reason it's not "over".  Everyone knows about cancer, but no one knows cancer until they've been through it.  Eileen:  Oh how well I can relate to you with your daughter!  Last week, it was the emergency with my daughter having at least one abcsess tooth.  The week before, it was car trouble.  The same week, and part of the week before, it was someone stealing her bank card.  On and on and on.  Tonight, the other one calls me to tell me she has some type of infection.  My advice is always the same... get medicine from the drug store, call the doctor, make an appointment, if it's too bad, go to an urgent care.  And I understand about the breast feeding too.  I did all I could to make enough milk for my babies.  My body didn't want to cooperate, so I had to have a bit of help from medications.  It is something special and the bond that is created goes deep.  Glad she can do it!  I do hope your daughter's lymph node goes down and whatever caused it never comes back!!  Just keep on top of it.

Posts.Content: Dec 3, 2010 03:13AM cc4npg wrote: Thanks... just kinda hanging in there.  It's a lot to take in and I know it's not the end of the world, but it sure isn't fair either.  In the process of finding such centers for her.  Her public health nurse is helping, and so is the genetic counselor.  She's been on BCMH since birth for her heart.  I didn't want either of them to have it.  It makes me feel... like I've given her the plague or something, although I know it's not that bad.  But still, you don't want your babies to inherit such a thing.  You want more for them... better for them... and to be able to fix things if possible for them, but this... this is something that was passed from one generation to the next, and I don't even know where it came from yet.  It's just something you never want to hear that your kids have gotten from you.  It'll be ok.  God is still in control and knows all about it.

Posts.Content: Dec 3, 2010 11:50PM cc4npg wrote: My daughter is 19.  She has a ventricular septal defect, mitral valve prolapse, has had problems with irritable kidney since 16, this year had what we believe was an ovarian cyst burst, and was also born with tibial torsion.  Her heart still has the defect... tiny hole... doesn't give her problems.  The tibial torsion seems to have straightened out as she grew.  Her main problems now are the kidney issues and ovarian thing from earlier this year.  Obviously, if she is dx with some sort of breast cancer, it's of major concern to her heart.  So I don't want her to suffer with any of this.  All we can do is pray and get things looked at to make sure everything is ok for now.  Prayer works miracles, and if it's not your time to go, then no matter what the circumstances, you ain't goin no where.  That's the way I look at it.  She is young and the counselor assures us we're staring to watch this at a very good age.  Being that I developed BC at 43, and my sister at 41, I feel she has time to figure out what she wants to do.  And science is always coming up with new ideas and maybe even will find an actual cure/vaccine.  It's just a glich in our DNA, and I've a feeling this is just one tiny glich that we know about.  They'll eventually come up with all kinds of gliches leading to all kinds of health issues... give them time. I'm 4 days post 1st treatment of TC.  Doing very well.  Feel pretty much normal.  I have a few small red bumps along my neck/chest.  That's it really.  Not relishing the thought of hair loss coming soon, but it's winter and everyone is wearing hats anyway so it's the best time to have this happen.  I figure by May, I'll have some head cover again. Hope everyone continues healing well on this seemingly long journey!  Guys, it will get better.  Life is all about change.  Some good, some bad.  Right now, it's kinda the pits, but it'll get back to being better again!

Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2010 04:52AM cc4npg wrote: Well, today started out at about 4 a.m. with fever of 101.  I thought to myself, what the heck is going on... why does it keep coming back?  And then it struck me, that the only thing I did right before bed at 12:30 a.m. was take my antibiotic.  I looked up augmentin for a side effect of fever, and it can happen as an allergy.  So today I d/c it and took Keflex instead.  My fever has been gone most of the day.  This evening I had a 99.5, took tylenol, feel fine.  I don't know for sure it was the augmentin, but if I'm ever on it again, I'll see if it happens again.  And I had discomfort in my upper back... it's gone too.  I really hope I'm not becoming sensitive to so many drugs... Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2011 11:33AM cc4npg wrote: I'm getting ready for surgery too, coming up Feb 28.  Having ooph and exchange.  I don't seem to be nervous hardly at all with the surgery this time.  Give me versed and we're good to go!  Anesthesia worried me the first time, but they know what they're doing and my mx went really smoothly so I have no reason to think this will be any different.  I'm more worried about SE's from the ooph and getting my hair to grow back now that I'm done with chemo than I am about the actual surgical procedure. I'm also still trying to get my daughter, who is BRCA2+, in to see a doc.  Having significant trouble with finding one who will take her insurance.  I can find them all day long who do pediatrics, but my daughter is now 19 so we're having a problem. I've had some stress recently and is anyone else feeling unable to cope as well as before?  I'm noticing when something happens my heart races and I get really nervous, whereas I didn't used to have that problem as much.  Is that part of what menopause does?  I know I'm in chemical menopause.  I hate the heat associated with the hormones doing whatever they're doing!  Last night I was literally burning up and even tossing off the covers didn't help.  I just layed real still and relaxed until it started easing up, but it isn't comfortable at all.  With the ooph coming up, and instant menopause, I wonder if it'll be about the same or worse?   Weather in Ohio has been gorgeous this week!  Warm... in the 60's!  Got some clean up done from last years plants yesterday... I didn't do anything from September on because of all the mental stress I had from my dx.  My energy level seems pretty much back to before dx.  My fingernails HURT though!  Hoping that goes away.  Can't open soda and other things really hurt.  Also I've noticed a significant decrease in strength to open things, like jars.  All in all though, I think I'm doing well.  Wish these little white hairs on my head would thicken up and darken, but I'm not quite 3 weeks pfc even so I know I'm really expecting a lot at this point and lucky to have little white hairs showing up like I do already!

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2010 07:51PM cc4npg wrote: Got home a little while ago.  My surgery was yesterday at 10 a.m.  I arrived at 8:30, got undressed, had a pregnancy test done (normal procedure).  I told them I was very anxious/nervous.  The surgeon came in to talk to me, and gave me the sentinel node shot.  It wasn't bad.  They didn't numb for it and he went very slow.  I felt slight stinging, and more like a pressure sting.  The shot was at the 12 o'clock position, right above the areola.  They then gave me some versed in my iv.  I remember just a little bit after that was given, and then I was hearing my name, and that my son was watching for me.  I was being wheeled into the room on a bed... it was OVER!  I was pretty out of it last night, but I did walk to the bathroom.  I had a catheter, and it was taken out as soon as I got to the room.  I didn't have a sore throat at all. The pain was not as bad as I thought it'd be.  It's more a pressure ache, but I have felt some burning pain in a couple of areas which thankfully went away quickly.  I told them no morphine prior to surgery, because my family doesn't handle morphine well.  I was given Zofran for nausea and Vicotin for pain.  The Vicotin makes me itch, so they gave me Benedryl with it.  Going from lying to sitting hurt, especially at first.  First time up to the bathroom was interesting... I was still woozy and weak from anesthesia, but I made it.   They took 3 sentinel nodes, and the preliminary results, which they say are 95% accurate, were NEGATIVE!  I don't have a stage yet.  I'm a bit nervous for final pathology, but I think so far I've been given good news.  My original biopsy showed no vascular/lymphatic invasion, so I'm very hopeful. I notice I can't feel much under my arms... it's weird numb feeling.  My fingers/hands feel a little swollen/stiff.  My shoulder blades are stiff/achy.  I've been doing the breathing thing, and can get up to 2000... I can't remember what this breathing apparatus is called. So anyway, I'm on the other side of it now and feel like a huge weight has been lifted!  I don't think I'll really miss the boobs that tried to kill me.

Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2010 01:59AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 11:56AM by cc4npg Hi guys!  Yesterday was a little rough for me... had some lingering pain and still felt foggy.  I broke down and took a half percocet last night and was able to finally sleep in a real bed!  Today, I feel like I've made a turning point and feel pretty good, although still tired.  I noteced today that my sides, under my arms, look puffy.  I don't feel any jiggling, but it's definitely puffy.  Did anyone else have this happen?  I'm assuming it is probably a little fluid, after all they did take the drains out Monday.  I had only drained 8 ml from each during the prior 24 hours though.  The pressure sensation or rubber band feeling is much less today and I actually sneezed!!  That was a little scary, but it went fine.  Still no final pathology... and I'm nervous only because of all the bad news I've had over the past month and a half.  My doc hasn't told me anything about oncology yet and I assume he's waiting on final path.  I go back to my PS Monday to get stitches removed.  They told me Monday to start stretching, finger walking up walls, etc.  I can raise both arms straight over my head.  Sideways my right is about 95%, my left is probably 90%.  When I clasp my hands behind my head and stretch like a butterfly, that's a little harder... right one better than the left.  I think the range is really good for not even a week out though. HappyGirl45 and faith22:  Sending positive thoughts and hoping you're recovering well!  Let us know how you are when you can! mom38yo:  I had NS bmx Oct 7th... cancer on the left, prophy right, triple negative, grade 2, no stage yet, BRCA2 positive.  They took 3 nodes and say preliminary results at time of surgery looked negative for cancer and believe that will stay true for final path.  They took a core biopsy at time of surgery under my left nipple too, and it also came back negative during surgery.  I had immediate reconstruction but they only put 25 ml in at the time.  I was a small A cup and honestly I look almost the same size as before surgery.  I didn't have valium the night before, but asked for Versed as soon as possible that morning and remember nothing except talking to the BS prior to surgery... then I was being wheeled back into my room and it was over.  I was a wreck prior to surgery.  Today marks my 6th day out, and I took Extra Strength Tylenol yesterday, 1/2 Percocet last night, and only had 2 Tylenol this morning.  I plan on taking at least a 1/2 Percocet again tonight to help me rest.  The TE's feel like rocks to me.  I'm mostly numb from the nipple up to my collar bone and have feeling from the nipple down.  Armpits have feeling now.  And thank God, I have what appears to be complete feeling in my right nipple!   Janet: I haven't had anything like that.  The weird thing I noticed was with my vision, which seems to be clearing up.  My left eye has always been better and clearer, but my right seems to be now.  It may straighten out.  The tight rubber band feeling is way less, and now the feeling I have is similar to when I was breastfeeding and was full... very strange but I'll take that over pain!

Posts.Content: Oct 27, 2010 12:15AM cc4npg wrote: prayersanswered:  Will say a prayer for you.  Ask them for something to help settle nerves when you go in.  I didn't get any type of pill to take prior to going in, but when I got there I told them (honestly) that I was extremely anxious (scared, terrified) and they gave me Versed as soon as I'd talked to the BS.  I remember 5 minutes "maybe" after that, and then I was waking up.  Yes, Versed is my new friend. I have had some emotional moments recently.  I still contribute it to all the trauma and meds.  My mind drifts into areas that I shouldn't even be thinking about.  I've got 3 kids, breastfed each one, my baby will be 3 next week (maybe that's triggering some of it).  I absolutely loved nursing my baby and at 43 I probably wouldn't have had more children, although right before diagnosis, believe it or not, we toyed with the idea.  And it got to me today... I'm officially done with those years... childbearing or otherwise.  I completely forgot about the fact I'm BRCA2+ as I was remembering past pregnancy and nursing.  I know I wouldn't bring another child into the world knowing I could pass that to them.  I have 3 kids... and I am blessed to have had children because many who have the BRCA haven't.  I think it's just everything hitting at once.  Like I said in another post, we go thru this on adreneline and then it starts sinking in.   I still continue healing well.  I've not had a nap during the day since I came home from the hospital. Having an almost 3 yr old and not a lot of help, I didn't have a choice.  I've been driving since  Oct 17th... took myself to church because no one was available and I was determined to get there.  I have a bit of seroma on my non cancer side but it's not really painful.  My TE's were only filled 25 ml during surgery, so that probably has an effect on recovery.  First fill is next Monday, the 1st.  I'm nervous for it only because I don't know what to expect, but after going thru what I've been thru, I figure it'll be a piece of cake.  My incisions look wonderful... steri strips off today and gonna take pictures for the picture forum in a while.  I think they'll be almost invisible once done.  I guess today is just a down day... plus it's cloudy and I dislike winter greatly (always gotten depressed during the winter)... AND I'm in Ohio so today we had all these major storms come thru with tornado warnings left and right!  But mainly I got myself down by reminiscing, which has wonderful memories.  Wish I could go back and relive them, but I think I'm going to get off the computer and go play with my little boy... and make NEW ones instead!

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2010 04:23PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 12:04PM by cc4npg boatergrl:  Sorry to see you here but glad you found us!  You'll find this entire forum very helpful along the way. The burning sensation is definitely normal and I've heard it related to both nerves regrowing and a "phantom" feeling after a breast is removed.  I've read that this phantom feeling occurs in people who have had a limb removed too.  Whatever the case, and I lean more toward nerve growth, it usually dissipates over time.  I had a slight burning, more like medium discomfort, going from sitting to laying and vice versa.  I had nipple sparing bmx 10/7, and actually last night I had quite an uncomfortable night of sleeping.  Mine, I believe, was due to a seroma that has been reabsorbed so my right side is now feeling some discomfort from the expander or whatever.  I feel actually wonderful this morning, so maybe that part is over.  But that just gives you an idea that you'll have good and bad days, but will notice an increase overall with good.  Yes, use alcohol pads for the drains.  I actually used gloves too, so that I'd keep everything sterile.  I agree with Janet, you'll feel all kinds of strange things... zaps, stings, itching, burning, twinges of pain if you move a certain way.  The things to keep an eye on are increased swelling, redness, feverish skin, fever, and any drainage that resembles infection.  If in doubt, call your doctor. Sleeping... I think we all just kind of did our best the first few days.  Recliners are your friend.  Pillows under the arms help.  After drains come out, you may be able to very carefully figure out how to lay on your side.  Keep the pain meds coming.

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2010 06:50PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 06:05AM by cc4npg I have a moment and was catching up with posts.  I'm glad to hear we are continuing to heal, and so happy that additional surgeries and procedures are turning out well.  I have read of staph and even mrsa infections after mx, small necrosis areas, and blues.  True, many people die from other causes than BC.  My cousin's wife had a massive heart attack when I was dx and she's maybe 45.  Her heart is so damaged now (thankfully alive) that she can't walk hardly, can't work, and they don't know what they're going to do.  I think the hard part with any type of cancer is knowing you have it or have had it, and always wondering if it's come back.  There are so many long term survivors, who I believe would say they had cancer at one point in their life.  I keep running into them every day, and most aren't online.  It all takes a toll psychologically as well as physically.  So far, I've not had to start any type of antidepressants or antianxiety meds.  But I've wondered a few times if I needed them.  It's emotional.  Most often, I try to think of something other than what's making me down but the mind wanders into areas it shouldn't for all of us and it's completely normal.  With time, we learn how to regain control of the "normalcy" we now have but we may need some help along the way in terms of medication or someone to talk to.  So far, this board has been my "someone to talk to".  Meditation, yoga, faith, accupuncture, massage... all different avenues people have used.  BC invaded our lives and privacy... it crept up and stole parts of us that can't be replaced.  You guys provide me with strength and support and I'm amazed at your strength!  It's soooo cold here!  Ok, I'm rubbing it in.  It's 97 in Cali.

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2010 04:58AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 12:11PM by cc4npg AnnetteS:  You just had your surgery 10/27 right??  If my dates are correct, then you are experiencing everything NORMAL.  I only had 3 nodes removed from one side, and yes I do believe it makes a difference in recovery.  You're a little over 2 weeks out.  I know reaching my armpits was difficult for me at that point.  You have to reach across your chest to get to your armpit, and those movements are tender.  I started massaging at about 2 1/2 weeks out, so you're getting to that point.  However, I started stretching on day 4 after surgery because my drains came out that day.  I was determined to get my arms straight over my head quickly, so I did finger walks up the wall.  I had most movement back quicker if I faced the wall and walked up that way.  However, if I stood with my side toward the wall and tried walking my fingers up sideways (whichever arm was facing the wall), I noticed it was harder to do.  Finally, the stretching done when lying on the floor with hands clasped behind your head (elbows bent) and slowly stretching them out toward the floor was the hardest for me.  I think that stretch helped the most with reaching the armpits though.  After I mastered that most of the way, I would stretch while sitting in the car by half turning and reaching my arm back as far as I could.  That hurt quite a bit at first, but I have a toddler and he constantly wants me to reach something back to him, so he was my therapy. A word of caution on massaging with lotion.  Make sure your incisions appear to be healed with no raw areas.  I wouldn't have started if I'd still had some raw places, because of the fear of infection.  I was very careful and cautious the first time since I have no feeling in some areas and didn't know how hard I could push.  Over time, you'll get used to how everything feels inside and out.  But yeah, it was pretty creepy feeling the TE edges when I started... that and the lack of sensation was just weird. Also, if you still have drains, be really careful not to get anything around the tubing that goes inside.  I didn't massage while I had drains and hopefully you'll get them out really soon!  Just hang in there for now... things will get better tremendously after those come out!

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2010 11:54PM cc4npg wrote: Ndwmel:  From what I read in your other posts, you had unilateral mx?  And you'll be having a TE put in perhaps after Thanksgiving?  Well, I'm not sure how it feels to wake up w/o a TE, but I can tell you that the pain you felt after your mx gets better, and so will the discomfort from the TE.  TE's feel like... an iron bra?... or a tight rubber band around your breasts??... or like you have a bra on that's way tight.  They're harder than breast tissue and they feel "alien" until you get used to them.  But, the best news is, you'll get to the point where there's very little discomfort and you almost forget you have them.  Your range of motion will come back, just do the excersizes when your dr gives you the ok.  You will be emotional about all the trauma you've been through and are going through.  We're all emotional and we all have really super days and not so super days, but this board and the people on it will be such a great resource and outlet for all your questions/worries/concerns/joys... you'll be understood here and we'll do everything we can to help you from our own experiences. I don't know if you'll have another drain when the TE is placed, but it's something to ask the PS.  Ask him about pain/discomfort, as well as when you can shower/excersize.  You'll want to keep out your button up tops.  I only wore them for 4 days, but my drains came out really soon (at 4 days out).  Also ask the PS how much he will fill at time of surgery, which varies according to how tight the TE is under the muscle.  Trust me, you don't want him to fill it more than he suggests.  The discomfort comes (from my understanding) from filling too much too quick.  Many women have the other side augmented, so ask the PS opinion on that.  Finally, there is a picture forum here that will show you results from other people who have gone thru this.  I very highly suggest looking into being approved to see this forum.  Timtam is the one who gives the permission and password, but there are a few other women on the board here who can help you.  If you have difficulty finding Timtam's profile to send a pm, let me know. Well guys, I was busy today!  I saw the BS, PS, and went to the Look Good, Feel Better Class!!  BS is THRILLED with my results thus far, and requested pictures so he can use them for other patients/presentations he does for nipple sparing mx.  The PS was also quite pleased with results thus far, and feel my final result will be great.  The Look Good, Feel Better class was awesome.  I got some make up (part of which I may not use), some scarves/hats, and a wig!  My insurance won't cover a wig, so that was a plus.  It's not exactly like my hair now, but better than nothing!  I'm also going to call Locks of Love and see if they have any kind of wigs.  There were only two of us in the class today, and the other lady was taking 6 rounds of TC and was half way done.  She really hadn't suffered any great side effects, so that was really good to hear/see.  My whole week is busy.  I have at least two more dr visits this week, one being my onc on Thursday.  And maybe my ears heard wrong, but I thought I heard something about possible SNOW (that four letter word) on Thursday!  Yuk... give me the 90's I just left in Cali!  Hope you all are having a fabulous week!!  If it's warm where you are, go out and enjoy it for me!

Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2010 02:44AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 12:18PM by cc4npg Emotional wounds are often overlooked!  We're so intent on making sure we're doing everything we can, and surviving what we're going through, that by the time we actually stop long enough for the reactions to set in, WHAMO!... depression... anxiety... sadness... loss... fear.  We need to focus on healing from the inside out, or at least try to.  And remember we are going to have moments where we just break down for reasons others won't understand.  Often, my fiance' will come in and see I've been crying, asks me what's wrong, and I just say "it all just hit me again".  Being that I'm the last living person in my particular family doesn't help.  Mom died 4 yrs ago in a head on collision, dad died at 36 after leaving us 2 yrs prior, both grandma's died two and three years ago, grandfather's gone too.  That's why I come here for support, and I of course reach out to those around me but there aren't many here.  Most people "sent" my way are ones I don't know.... literally "sent" to me to let me know the big guy has heard my prayer... from the electric company rep to my recent homeowners claim adjustor to the first lady at my church that I blurted out I had breast cancer to when I found out... all survivors.  But this forum is so helpful and supportive.  The women here legit care for each other and try their best to help each other through this.  I've been to a lot of forums, and there are many women there too, but this one seems the most consistent and largest. Just FYI... I think we have to be crazy or touched in the head a little to survive this, and letting out our emotions is good to achieve survival.  If we didn't, we'd dig a hole, curl up in a ball, and never come out again.

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2010 05:28AM cc4npg wrote: imatthew:  Hi!  I hope your wife is healing well and glad this part is over for the two of you.  I would recommend you ask for a copy of your final pathology report.  That will tell you a lot more, and trust me, you will re-read it several times.  You could also take a small recorder to the BS appt... you won't remember everything he says while you're there.  Questions... well, I'll be honest, here's part of what I asked.  When can I drive?  When can I start excersizes? What kind of excersizes should I do?  How much can I lift?  Do I have any other restrictions (swimming, walking, intimacy)? Should I be wearing any kind of supportive bra or camisole, and if so, what kind?  How do the incisions look? Do you see any signs of seroma?  When can I get the drain tubes out?  Should I be massaging the scars or breasts to break up scar tissue?  If not now, when can I?  Can I put special cream on the scars to make them less visible, and if so, what would you recommend?  Are the pains/aches/feelings of pins and needles normal?  How can I tell if I'm expanding my lungs to the fullest amount?  Are there any other tests we can get to establish what, if any, chemo may be necessary (oncotype, MRI, PET, etc)?  Do you feel I need to consider any genetic testing?  Do you feel I may need to consider having ovaries removed?  If I need chemo, will I have a port?  How long will it be before I start chemo or rads?  If I decide to get another opinion, do I need to have you refer me? You have the other's that I asked... and may come up with more from what I just mentioned.

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2010 12:53AM cc4npg wrote: Hi guys... hope your fever goes away.  I think it's normal to run a low grade fever for a short time, the anesthesia can cause it.  However, you need to watch that because it could be normal or it could be mild infection.  My seroma has almost gone away!  I've had a little more discomfort on that side today, so I looked and was amazed to see the puffiness gone.  My discomfort has been coming from what "feels" like under my shoulder blade at the back.  Just kind of an achey feeling and hurts some when I move a certain way, then goes away, and comes back once I've relaxed again.  If I push my shoulders back and stand real straight, it seems to help.  My left side had been hurting to begin with, so I figure with the swelling down now, I may be feeling some soreness. My son got a full bucket of candy last night!  He's been munching on it unfortunately, but we usually don't give him candy.  So many cute kids out last night!  One of the houses in the area we go always has cider and donuts... GOOD donuts... and different varieties.  So we got a treat too!  Some of the homes give full size candy bars, and the church always has hot dogs, hot cocoa, and coffee.   Excited for tomorrow... first fill!  I have a couple larger bras because I'm not sure what size I'll get.  It doesn't feel as weird now when my son is sitting on my lap.  It's still numb, but since most of the pain is gone, I think either I'm getting used to it or it's actually feeling not as "alien".  I still believe a good deal of the feeling will come back to the upper breast, but it'll take time and I may not even realize it's happening.  Just glad both nipples look wonderful, and to have feeling in the right one.  The scars are healing nicely.  I started using a special lotion and massaging them just a little to help with blood flow and scar tissue break up. I believe I may watch a scary movie in a bit.  But first I'm going to Henna my hair (or my significant other is).  It may be my last time doing it if I have chemo.  Very frightened of side effects now... afraid of memory problems, vision changes, neuropathy, and long term possible effects.  The oncologist said something can happen to the bone marrow later down the line.. doesn't happen with everyone but to some.  Still praying the university determines only DCIS, but then I'll most definitely need to have a 3rd opinion.  I'll happily get it if there's a chance of only DCIS but not getting hopes up too much.

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2010 02:53AM cc4npg wrote: myrrl:  Great news!  I think the antibiotics are working.  I also try not to talk about everything I'm feeling to my family.  Some things they feel I'm obsessing about, and it's just not true.  I don't think anyone can truly understand the thoughts and emotions we go thru unless they've been there.  And I truly believe this forum is filled with people who have felt it, so anything we might say would be understood.  I know I would have over obsessed without this forum... it helped to read other posts of almost exactly what I was feeling and kept me from thinking I might be nearing a breakdown.  Knowing so many others have been there helps me know I will get through it. Hope everyone has a good evening.  It's freezing here in Ohio... and it's supposed to be in the 90's in California this week!  Now that's my kind of weather!

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2010 10:53AM cc4npg wrote: Hi guys... just checking in quickly.  Some thoughts... DCIS normally isn't tested for Her2 I don't believe.  But get a second opinion... you can't go wrong there!  If by a stroke of miracle mine turns out DCIS w/microinvasion or all DCIS then I will need a 3rd opinion to figure out what treatment is needed.  I'm hoping I need a 3rd opinion, honestly, but we'll see.  Either way, God is in control.  alhaun:  You're normal.  Between emotions and medication, you're depressed and yes the meds take a while to get out of your system.  I had the crying too, not terribly bad, and I tried to cover it up so it wasn't that noticeable.  But I think it was like two weeks for me, and I still have down moments.  It's to be expected.  So sorry to hear about the chemo!  You need a break! I see my BS for the first time since surgery on the 15th.  I too am seeing more of the PS for follow up and I think that's the norm.  Still no word on my daughter's BRCA testing or my retesting of tissue at OSU.
Posts.Title: October 2010 Mastectomy cc4npg cc4npg

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2010 10:06AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 06:07AM by cc4npg I hope everyone remembered to set their clocks back one hour.  Just checking in quickly.  I'm glad to hear your fever went down myrrl.  As for a positive node alhaun, maybe it's just microscopically positive so make sure to ask.  I've read so many posts from people with no node involvement to people with 15/17 positive to know you can't go on that for prognosis.  There are many people 10+ years out with multiple nodes involved, and there are some with no nodes involved that have had recurrences.  It tears you up emotionally.  Praying for no vascular invasion!!  I'm doing much better emotionally while here in a warm, sunny climate.  Weather definitely plays a role on the mind, some of us more than others.  I've been trying to forget I "had" breast cancer, and am attempting to look at it that way.  I'm not looking forward to going back to the cold at all, but I'm going to try to get involved in other things when I get back that may take my mind off it.  Pain has been minimal, just discomfort here and there.  Energy isn't quite where it was, but it's getting there.  I've not been doing well with diet, but who can when they're out of town?  I'm counting on God to bless what I do eat so it won't hurt me, because at 100 lbs (was like 103), I have to gain a little weight.  Hope you all have a wonderful Sunday!

I'm the one they call in my family too.  And this week, I've partially solved two.  My daughter needed help with food, so I took her shopping.  She also finally went to a dentist for some pain, and looks like she may have 1-3 root canals coming... big infection... front lower teeth.  So I had to call her insurance company, talk to them, find an endodontist, set up an appointment, etc.  Looks like I'll be going back to Columbus this week, not for me, but for her, to get this taken care of.  Meanwhile, my dishwasher decided to spring a major leak.  So today, instead of mopping my floor, I had to call my ins company to get emergency people out.  My laminate floor is ripped up, my carpet is wet, and I have 8 industrial fans running for the next 24-48 hours! Other than that, I'm doing really well with healing and feel really good physically.  It's the mental part I sometimes worry about!  LOL

Posts.Content: Dec 6, 2010 03:12PM cc4npg wrote: Yes, we are, and we absolutely LOVE our job!  Well, obviously I'm not working right now, but I miss my people and they ask about me often.  Funny thing happened my 1st round of chemo.  I'm sitting there and suddenly I see a familiar face.  Turns out one of my past residents wife was there taking chemo!  It was literally the highlite of my day.  I enjoy people, listening to them, helping them.  I feel a little out of place around people my own age sometimes.  I have way more in common with the older generation because, as I think I posted in another thread somewhere, I feel I was raised in that era.  Normal families tell stories about their past, but mine concentrated on it, as if it was high importance to make sure the next generation knew the stories as if they'd lived through them.  Details were carefully included, visits were made to homesteads, graveyards where things had taken place were also visited.  We interviewed people who knew the family, asking questions, documenting everything and even recording it.  Amazing how things jump to life when families go into that much depth!  So at 43, I feel like I've lived through the 20's, the depression, the war, and all of that.

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2010 02:58PM cc4npg wrote: Well it's been a LONG week for me!  So Monday night... 7 days out post chemo.. developed fever 100.4, went up to 100.9 overnight.  Tuesday morning 99.9, ate some bkfst, called onc office and left message with a real person about fever at 8 a.m.  No call back by 11 a.m., called, left another message.  Laid on couch literally ALL day with aches, mild chills, probable fever.  2 p.m. Tuesday, temp was a whopping 102.2!  Now I'm a little scared.  Called probably more than a dozen times before reaching a real person at onc office and demanded to speak to someone.  Went to onc office for cbc at 4:30.  Three people, one being the onc, come to the door after my bloodwork and usher me back.  White count plummeted to 800 or .8!!!  Gave neupogen and called hospital to get me directly admitted.  Got to the hospital about 7 p.m., after a minor detour to get Aleve and Claritan.  I was only supposed to be there 24 hours.  I just got out yesterday afternoon... While there, standard procedure I guess is to place a heart monitor on.  Never had one and my heart tends to beat a bit faster, sometimes in the upper 90's, occassionally in the 120's, and if I'm highly aggitated or a major issue has just happened, it can go to 140.  So I had one, and heart was racing.  While laying in bed, it was around 120's.  I had test after test for the white count... chest x ray, blood cultures, urine cultures.  It slowly rose from .8 to 1.3 in 24 hours, then to 2.2 by 48 hours.  The onc was going to release me, but the heart was still of concern.  After walking in the hall, it went to 157, so a cardiologist was called in.  I then underwent an EKG, CT with contrast, and Echocardiogram, as well as thyroid blood check.  In the meantime, I was extremely frustrated and irritated with the whole thing!  My heart is normally high, not quite like this, so what changed?  It was high on arrival they said, so what happened?  Neupogen happened.  I came here and searched for neupogen and found it has done this to others... tachycardia.  It's rare, but it's even on their website as a side effect.  None of the docs had heard of this, and I don't think they still believe the chemo or neupogen has something to do with it.  But I've read it here too.  Anyway, long story short, I came home. Now I have three specialists to follow up with:  Oncologist (for BC), Pulmonologist (for lung nodules believed to be histoplasmosis), Cardiologist (for poss tachycardia) OMG... 2010 cannot end soon enough!  This is seriously nuts!  I'm really thankful I've had so many people praying and thinking of me, but being on that oncology unit in the hospital was like being on death row.  One person even died while I was there right who was right in my same area!

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2011 04:17AM cc4npg wrote: Cathie:  This is the one place you can come and whine all you want... but we all know you're not whining at all... cuz we all have these feelings.  None of us know when we will be "well" again, or if the underlying fear that we try to mask will ever truly be just a memory that fades.  I have no clue right now, but I do know the fear surrounding this.  I try to make myself realize that death or something bad can happen to anyone at any time, so this dx doesn't mean I won't have a full life.  But it does haunt me... so far... and I must be honest that it does so each of us will know we are NORMAL in what we're feeling.  I have had some really good moments where I'll forget I've had this dx, but it's still vivid in my mind.  We are still fresh from being dx though, still have expanders, still in treatment (some of us), and still taking meds for x years (some of us).  I try to pull myself up from slipping into a down mood... often it works... sometimes it doesn't.  My heart rate hasn't shot up into the 150's to my knowledge any more.  It has become faster though, especially if I become upset over something.  I have to really be careful not to get very upset or anxious over family happenings.  If someone hurts my feelings or something, for instance, I can't allow myself to dwell on it and become upset.  My heart and bp have a tendency to shoot up when that happens.  So far, so good. Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2011 03:12AM cc4npg wrote: I think they're coming along with finding a cure or at least other drugs that inhibit growth while killing cancer cells.  They're getting closer.  I wouldn't be a bit surprised to find that what we've been calling cancer is actually several different types of disease that cause this effect of cells mutating and replicating... but it may have totally different reasons it's doing it.  BRCA is just one of those such things.  If I had been born without the genetic disorder, I might never have gotten cancer.  Perhaps stem cell research will help in correcting this type of defect, who knows? Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2011 10:05PM cc4npg wrote: Well I think everything is fine.  Pretty much, the nodules are still there but there is a suggestion of calcification going on with larger ones... which is good.  Cancerous nodules do not calcify, so you want calcification to happen with nodules.  I also have mild bronchiectasis, so he ordered some blood work to rule out any other kind of disease.  I will have a repeat ct scan in 6 months, but he really feels these have been there for a while and aren't of concern.  I will be followed for 3 years.  Normally they follow nodules for 2 years to make sure they're not growing, but since I have the BC dx, and chemo, he wants to follow an extra year and I agree with that. You would not believe how sick I was last year from March to June.  Looking back, I should have gone to urgent care in the beginning with the illness, because I'd never really had anything like it.  I had this general feeling of being sick and remember being so very tired.  I would be doing charting (nurse aide) and there were a few times I remember literally nodding off while sitting there.  It took everything I had just to focus and gain energy!  Then the strange fevers came... "cyclic fever" is what they called it.  It would come early afternoon, then build up into evening.  I'd go to bed, only to wake up in the wee a.m. hours soaking wet with the fever breaking.  And it'd start all over again.  Then it would go away and come back a week later.  And finally the cough that became worse and worse to the point I could not say the words "how are you today" without coughing horribly.  I should have known something was not right, but I thought I had a virus.  The junk I coughed up was ridiculous.  I went in after coughing up blood one night, and the rest is history.  Never have coughed blood since thank goodness, and all symptoms went away after finishing antibiotics.

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2010 01:28AM cc4npg wrote: I went to the plastic surgeon today.  Bandages off, and drains out!  Wow, I must say, getting the drains out was a weird feeling.  I can't really say it was painful, but it was such a weird feeling and I was already nervous about it.  The smaller of the two did hurt a little coming out, while the larger one actually didn't feel bad and was quicker coming out.  I get stitches out next Monday.  I didn't look as weird as I thought I would.  There was very little bruising.  They put in 25 ml during surgery, and I don't look much smaller than I did before surgery.  It's just that totally numb weird feeling that freaks me out at the moment!  I can raise my arms up almost straight, and now I'm working on full range of motion.  I had more pain today than usual, probably because the drains came out.  I expect there's a healing process to be expected but I will be glad when some feeling starts coming back to the upper breast.  My first fill will be 3 weeks from surgery.  They want everything to settle down first.  I figure my BS will call me soon with final pathology... nervous about that, but hopeful that things stay good news this time.  I've had enough bad news for a while. Posts.Content: Oct 19, 2010 06:32PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 05:58AM by cc4npg prayersareanswered:  Hi!  Are you having reconstruction?  I can tell you I thought I was more afraid of the surgery... until I was done with surgery, then I started sweating bullets about final path!  I think it's the same with every test/surgery/report we go through, and I don't think it really changes all that much... it's stressful regardless of what it is.  I read up on every single study I could read about... read worst case scenarios... and tons of forum posts on triple negative people and how their stories had gone.  I made myself a complete mess, but one thing for sure, I was educated!  I wasn't given any medication to take prior to arriving for surgery, but as soon as I got back to a room, I requested Versed, which they administered right after I spoke to the BS.  I remember maybe 5 minutes after that, and then I was waking up, so I really love what Versed did for me!  You should ask your BS for something such as this maybe prior to surgery to help with anxiety.  As for the path results, it's hard not to be anxious, if not impossible.  I got my final path report 8 days after surgery, and it was good results.  (Oh, and I did my own stats on the triple negative board as to what percentage of people here ended up with negative vs. positive nodes, based it on tumor size, etc.. very in depth.. yeah, I was that bad prior to surgery) The things that helped me personally the most were my faith and seeing so many others who have lived long lives with a history of battling breast cancer at some point.  And knowing the stats are really in our favor for survival.  I did a lot of crying from 8/9/10 to 10/7/10, and still do some because this is something that's not "over" when it's over.  Our lives are changed forever by this disease, as is our way of thinking, and it's almost impossible for someone who hasn't gone thru it to understand why our emotions are a mess.  Plus, recently I've actually felt guilty for my mood swings because I think it makes others feel either guilty or compelled to try to help in some way and then I feel bad. My daughters had genetic testing today.  I'm very concerned about their results and don't want either to have this.  I know it doesn't mean they'll "get" BC, but still, I worry.  My half sister is also being tested.  My half sister and I are the only ones with BC.  The only family history unknown is from my father's father.  Dad died at 36 (suicide), and his dad died at 36 (cirrosis of liver, not alcohol result).  I don't know anything about that side and wish I'd done more geneology.  If my mother were alive, she would tell me if genetic testing was done on all of us, they'd find something weird somewhere in all of us. So I try not to let my mind wander too far. As for prophylactic mx... I completely am in favor of someone doing this prior to a cancer dx.  The results you want for final path on that would be negative, so eileen, you definitely did what I would have done.

Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2010 04:49PM cc4npg wrote: EastCoastGrl:  Your chemo would be the same as mine.  Yes, I've read that about the taxotere too.  My onc hasn't seen anyone who had that happen, so who knows.  The cold caps... well, it depends on if you have the people needed to use them.  I looked into it.  My Cancer Care Coordinator claims they don't work, and I think the whole reason they may be against it is because of this.  If you keep something ice cold on your head, and those cells are living, what are the chances of a lone cancer cell being there?  The taxotere is supposedly less invasive for SE than Taxol, which has more neuropathy.  I've read a whole bunch of people who have had taxotere and absolutely the majority do get their hair back... some even start toward the end of therapy.  Yeah, it's scary.  I don't want to do it either, but my onc really feels it's best due to my age and triple negative.  I fall in a gray zone... they don't know how big my invasive cancer was, so they can't rule out chemo being warranted.  If I don't have the chemo and cancer comes back, it may be much worse, so I'm going to follow the recommendation as much as I hate it. TE's... yes they're a pain.  Each morning I wake up and moving hurts, but once I'm up it's ok.  I look forward to having them removed.  "Iron bra"... definitely.  There are few descriptive words for them until you actually have them.
