Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2010 03:47AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 12:00PM by cc4npg Eileen:  Not sure if anyone tackled the question about the electric pins.  I'm a nurse aide, and have done extensive reading and research on this "beast" we have.  My understanding on the electric pin feeling is that those are nerve endings regenerating... which is excellent news.  It takes nerves a long time to regenerate, and granted, some don't.  But to me, it sounds like nerves coming back slowly.  However, I would definitely still call your doctor to verify this.  If you have any obvious signs of infection (redness, fever, yellow puss, anything weird), call the doc immediately. Now, as for your PBM... in my opinion... YOU DID THE R-I-G-H-T THING.  I had a bilat mx too, and the only thing they found left was tiny DCIS.  I know you're stressing wondering if you should have kept them, but you'd already had cancer and your decision was based on your personal experience with your breast problems, and the knowledge that you had the option to have them removed, thereby almost eliminating that risk for future problems.  Do we know that they would have become cancerous again? NO.  But we all know that if there is a recurrence, it could be much worse in terms of prognosis.  That's a chance, personally, I wasn't willing to take.  We can live without our boobs... but not without our life.  I haven't been stressing over the loss of my boobs, but I can tell you my emotions have been off the wall since surgery.  I had a similar thing happen after my last C section.  Keep in mind, especially if you're still taking meds, that sometimes medication can have an affect on you that will make you think and feel things that you otherwise wouldn't.  My family has a history of this very thing with certain meds, and especially morphine. Feel free to vent all you want here... get it all out.. say what's on your mind.  I'd bet money (if I was a betting person) that there are a lot of other women who have felt exactly the same way as you are now.  Focus on one day at a time... take deep breaths... remember the feelings prior to surgery... tell yourself over and over why you decided to have this done... and then tell yourself you did the best you could to save your life... and I believe that should enable you to continue healing.

Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2010 09:50PM cc4npg wrote: eileen:  Janet is right... I had trouble flushing the toilet for the first couple weeks too.  And to open a window?  Forget it!  My ribs below my breast are still sore!  Oh, and the PS said that was from all the muscles stretching... perfectly normal.  You've been thru major surgery!  I agree and say the same thing... take it easy and go slow.  Stay on top of pain meds.  Each of us heals different... one size does NOT fit all.  If the pain continues, give your doc a call and make sure everything seems normal to him. I have two older kids too.  Two daughters... 21 and 19.  Yup... heard that clock ticking and had my boy at 40!  My two older kids went with their dad to Alabama for a race.  Not sure which one.  But we're in Ohio, so that's definitely a trip!!  My son is looking forward to our upcoming trip to Cali.  I won't want to come back to this cold!  Yes, my house is very quiet.  And DARK at night!  We have no street lights.  Actually, we have no fire hydrants either!  Well water... no city water or sewer.  Propane... no city gas.  Now that's a pain in the winter!  We have typical windy weather "here"... kinda like Santa Anna winds... nothing to break the wind but corn or soy.  We have coyotes and deer.  No sidewalks.  No loud cars.  No one doing burnouts.  And you can actually go outside and scream if you're having a bad day without anyone calling the police!!  LOL
Posts.Title: October 2010 Mastectomy cc4npg cc4npg

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2010 11:10AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 06:05AM by cc4npg AnnetteS:  Sounds like a separate issue with the lower back.  Mine does that sometimes, but it's because my discs are already becoming a bit close together and osteoporosis is probably in my future so I have to be careful.  Might be an inflamed nerve, or pinched.  Maybe you've been laying the wrong way and a muscle is spasming. myrrl:  Glad to hear you're feeling better!  Just take it easy and enjoy the feeling.   I'm still healing, and I have some sharp zingers near the right nipple or off to the side at times.  I don't know if it's nerves healing or skin stretching from TE's, but either way it's not something I can't handle.  When they stitched the right side, there is a teeny tiny fold on the skin, like they overstitched in that area, so that may be trying to stretch out.  Otherwise doing fine.  I'm amazed that even in sunny, warm Cali I still have some down moments.  I start enjoying something, then all of a sudden, my brain remembers what I have yet to deal with... what a downer!  I sometimes wonder if hypnosis would help! LOL  I'm anxiously awaiting retest results, even though I've tried not to get my hopes up, it's hard not to "hope".  But then I read about triple negatives with tiny dcis or idc not getting chemo and ending up with mets... it's all so erratic.  Will check back in later tonight...

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2010 01:11PM cc4npg wrote: If you need pain meds, call the dr and experiment to see which one will work but not cause the depression.  I was first on Vicodin, then Darvocet, neither one I liked... but Percocet actually did well for me.  There are so many different pain meds out there that you shouldn't have to be in pain from fear of a reaction.  Each one reacts differently for each person, so just find your sweet spot, remember what the medication is that works, and ask for it every time your dr needs to prescribe something.

Posts.Content: Nov 25, 2010 07:04AM cc4npg wrote: Happy Thanksgiving guys!! I start chemo next week.  Just heard from onc today.  Ironically, my half sister started chemo the Monday after Thanksgiving when she was diagnosed 6 years ago.  Really weird.  I'm waiting on test results from a pulmonologist.  Earlier this year, in March, I had a really bad illness.  Started with feeling like the flu... achey, extremely tired, chills, and a cyclic fever that would come in the afternoon and break in the middle of the night with tremendous sweating (woke from that a few times).  Went on from March to late May... kinda on and off.  I developed a cough in late April which became worse and worse... very productive.  I finally went to the dr after I spit up some blood.  A round of antibiotics, two chest x rays, and a ct scan with contrast later... they determined I must have had a fungal infection called histoplasmosis.  I haven't had any cough since, so I figure I had a whopper of an infection.  Well, I wanted to see a pulmonologist back then, but they were booked up.  So last week I finally got in to see them and had an x ray and regular ct (no contrast).  He wasn't real concerned at the appointment... ran a breathing test while I was there... guessing I passed, nothing mentioned.  X ray had really nothing spectacular on it... maybe the hint of a nodule (but I had 3 nodules in June that didn't enhance, thus the probable infection).  So I called them today right before they closed, and the nurse said they couldn't give the results over the phone because the doctor hadn't been in this week and hadn't reviewed the results.  I figure if anything weird had come back, they would have called me, but I won't lie... it's stressful.  It's been a bad year for me, but then, I've had a rough time since 2006 honestly.   My energy is pretty much back to normal.  I had a fill on Monday, and have noticed it's harder to get comfortable at night.  The TE's seem to be squished together more now since they're filling out.  I'm a side sleeper.  I feel really good physically.  I'm not looking forward to chemo, but I'll gladly do it because I am much more afraid not to.  I realized today that I would be petrified any time I had a strange symptom if I didn't have chemo.  With chemo, I really feel I'll be more calm with aches or pains.   Have a good holiday guys!
